Description: Terracotta amulet-mould made of Nile clay; small sub-conical shaped mould with rough depression on back; impression of Bes head, crowned with four feathers, simple animal ears, and incised mane either side of chin; in orange-red Nile clay with a bluish-grey to reddish core; no visible remains of paste/glaze inside impression.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Scarab Factory (noted in Petrie's plate)
Dimensions: Depth: 0.90 millimetres (from surface of mould to bottom of impression)
Curator's comments: Impression identical to BM 1888,0601.747; size of mould also very similar, though colouring of clay is of slightly greyer hue.

In addition to glazed composition scarabs and scaraboids, the ‘Scarab Factory’ at Naukratis was also producing amulets (on the various productions from the Scarab Factory see Webb, forthcoming; see also Gorton 1996, 177-180, fig. 35). Petrie listed a number of different amulet-moulds, including one used for Bes head (Petrie 1886, 37, pl. XXXVIII, 14), which could be this specimen. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for dating, in R. Thomas (ed.), The Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 14.) (cast from such mould)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OJ.12) (phase 2)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2016, 19 May-27 Nov, BM exhibition Sunken Treasures
Condition: Some loss of surface of mould in top left hand corner, and a chip at bottom.
